--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> 
>=
 Yes. But be careful: separate business logic from application logic.
> 
> =
Application logic is code you write because you are a web application 
> us=
ing Struts.
> 
> Business logic is code you write because of the business p=
roblem you're 
> solving.

This is a very interesting and good point to me.=
 I did not think about
things from this angle. :) 

Anyone else has any fur=
ther comments about this ?

> 
> 
> So I would start with 1 business delega=
te per action. As the business 
> delegates begin to show some duplication,=
 I refactor them into an 
> increasingly rich domain model.

This approach =
sounds great to me. Keep it simple at the begining,
refactor it when it has=
 some "smell". 


> I like this approach, although I must say that I never =
used
StrutsTestCase.
> 

If you will use Struts, what testing tool you may =
use to test Action
related stuff ?


> Here's how to know it's business log=
ic: "Would I do this even if I 
> didn't have a computer?" That's business =
logic. The rest is application 
> logic. :)

That's pretty simple and impre=
ssive. hehe. 

> 
> > English is just my second language. I am not sure whe=
ther I express
> > myself clear enough. :(
>

 first language?

My native language is Chinese.

lated books, like "Junit In Action" and

h Junit", are already available in

uce your book to China ? I saw

r seen". I guess
